page.title: 01Sandringham and West Newton
page.content: Until 1862, this area was typical of the rural Norfolk which existed then and to a large extent now: a small village with its accompanying hamlets relying for work on the local landlord who needed agricultural workers in order to farm his estate. Since then, with the aquisition of the Sandringham Estate by The Royal Family, the area has gained an identity peculiar to itself. The visitor will notice immediately how well buildings and gardens are kept and the general feeling of well-being that permeates the atmosphere. For while still being the place where the estate workers live, it contains three generations who have lived in a 'Royal Village. The people who live here are indeed special themselves: friendly to the many annual visitors and very loyal to The Queen.
